segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management, and security considerations for the Accounts Block Microsoft accounts security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management, and security considerations for the Accounts Block Microsoft accounts security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management, and security considerations for the Accounts: Block Microsoft accounts security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management, and security considerations for the Accounts: Block Microsoft accounts security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting prevents users from adding new Microsoft accounts on a device.
segment.target: This policy setting prevents users from adding new Microsoft accounts on a device.

segment.source: If you click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option, users will not be able to switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account to drive sync, roaming, or other background services.
segment.target: If you click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option, users will not be able to switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account to drive sync, roaming, or other background services.

segment.source: This is the preferred option if you need to limit the use of Microsoft accounts in your enterprise.
segment.target: This is the preferred option if you need to limit the use of Microsoft accounts in your enterprise.

segment.source: Users will still be able to add app-specific Microsoft accounts for use with consumer apps.
segment.target: Users will still be able to add app-specific Microsoft accounts for use with consumer apps.

segment.source: To block this use, turn off the ability to install consumer apps or the Store.
segment.target: To block this use, turn off the ability to install consumer apps or the Store.

segment.source: If you click the Users can’t add or log on with Microsoft accounts setting option, existing Microsoft account users will not be able to log on to Windows.
segment.target: If you click the Users can’t add or log on with Microsoft accounts setting option, existing Microsoft account users will not be able to log on to Windows.

segment.source: Selecting this option might make it impossible for an existing administrator to log on to a computer and manage the system.
segment.target: Selecting this option might make it impossible for an existing administrator to log on to a computer and manage the system.

segment.source: If you disable or do not configure this policy (recommended), users will be able to use Microsoft accounts with Windows.
segment.target: If you disable or do not configure this policy (recommended), users will be able to use Microsoft accounts with Windows.

segment.source: Users can’t add or log on with Microsoft accounts
segment.target: Users can’t add or log on with Microsoft accounts

segment.source: By default, this setting is not defined on domain controllers and disabled on stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default, this setting is not defined on domain controllers and disabled on stand-alone servers.

segment.source: By disabling or not configuring this policy setting on the client computer, users will be able to use their Microsoft account, local account, or domain account for their sign-in session to Windows.
segment.target: By disabling or not configuring this policy setting on the client computer, users will be able to use their Microsoft account, local account, or domain account for their sign-in session to Windows.

segment.source: It also enables the user to connect a local or domain account to a Microsoft account.
segment.target: It also enables the user to connect a local or domain account to a Microsoft account.

segment.source: This provides a convenient option for your users.
segment.target: This provides a convenient option for your users.

segment.source: If you need to limit the use of Microsoft accounts in your organization, click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option so that users will not be able to create new Microsoft accounts on a computer, switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account.
segment.target: If you need to limit the use of Microsoft accounts in your organization, click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option so that users will not be able to create new Microsoft accounts on a computer, switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of the countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of the countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Although Microsoft accounts are password-protected, they also have the potential of greater exposure outside of the enterprise.
segment.target: Although Microsoft accounts are password-protected, they also have the potential of greater exposure outside of the enterprise.

segment.source: Additionally, if the owner of a Microsoft account is not easily distinguishable, auditing and forensics become more difficult.
segment.target: Additionally, if the owner of a Microsoft account is not easily distinguishable, auditing and forensics become more difficult.

segment.source: Require only domain accounts in your enterprise by limiting the use of Microsoft accounts.
segment.target: Require only domain accounts in your enterprise by limiting the use of Microsoft accounts.

segment.source: Click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option so that users will not be able to create new Microsoft accounts on a device, switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account.
segment.target: Click the Users can’t add Microsoft accounts setting option so that users will not be able to create new Microsoft accounts on a device, switch a local account to a Microsoft account, or connect a domain account to a Microsoft account.

segment.source: Establishing greater control over accounts in your organization can give you more secure management capabilities, including procedures around password resets.
segment.target: Establishing greater control over accounts in your organization can give you more secure management capabilities, including procedures around password resets.
